title: Double feature of Swedish Ingrid Bergman films
text:
We all know the Ingrid Bergman of “Casablanca.” Few know her early Swedish films, in which the orphaned teenager first demonstrated her star potential.
A retrospective by the Mill Valley Film Festival and Smith Rafael Film Center recognizing Bergman’s 100th birthday concludes Thursday, Oct. 22, with “Intermezzo” (1936) and “June Night” (1940).

“Intermezzo,” in which Bergman stars as a pianist in love with a world-famous married violinist, is especially of note. Directed by her mentor, Gustaf Molander , it is the film David O. Selznick saw that made him immediately offer her a contract (her first film for Selznick would be a remake, with Leslie Howard as the violinist).
Interestingly, Bergman, who was half German, had a lucrative offer from a German film studio, which she turned down. Good for all of us, it turns out.
— G. Allen Johnson 
“Intermezzo” and “June Night”: 6:30 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 22. Smith Rafael Film Center, 1118 Fourth St., San Rafael. (415) 454-1222. www.cafilm.org.
